runninghead.i: Chapter 20 Tateishi: Double Nominatives in Japanese
Chapter 20 Tateishi: Double Nominatives in Japanese

li.p: The Double Nominative Double Subject Construction
After Subjectivization: analyses on Double (Nominative) Subjects

subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: The existence of the Double Nominative Construction as in (1) is one of the peculiarities that linguists working on the Japanese language have always paid attention to:

(1)
Nihon -ga kokumin -no heikin jumyoo -ga mijika -i.
Japan NOM citizen GEN average lifespan NOM short PRES
‘It is Japan whose citizen's average lifespan is short.’

This construction is taken to be peculiar because it has been considered that the subject position and the Nominative Case assignment which usually comes with it are unique per clause. Sometimes the non-uniqueness of the subject/Nominative has been taken as evidence that Japanese lacks the notion subject in formal terms, and, at other times, the existence of such a construction has been regarded as the basis of parametrization on the function of the syntactic categories INFL/Tense/Agr/C(K)ase, as they are all said to be relevant to the Nominative Case assignment/checking. Some people notice the focal characteristic of the ‘outer’ subject and investigate where it comes from. Because the Double Nominative Construction does not fit into the ordinary scheme of the clausal structure [S NP [VP V NP]] with a unique subject per clause, the analysis of this construction has enough power to affect the theory of the clausal structure per se.

This case study presents and reviews some previous work on this peculiar construction and sees what issue is at stake and what the construction can tell us about the theory of the clausal structure. Section 2 introduces types of Double Nominative/Subject Constructions that exist in a single language called Japanese. As Japanese has another topic/subject marker -wa alongside the ordinary Nominative -ga, we cannot avoid mentioning how -wa and -ga interact with each other. Section 3 discusses the focal characteristic of some Double Nominative sentences. In this context, the rule ‘Subjectivization’ as a kind of focalization rule will be introduced. Section 4 overviews analyses of other types of Double Subject sentences not derived by Subjectivization. Section 5 introduces views on Case assignment/checking in relation to the Double Nominative Construction. The non-uniqueness of the Nominative Assignment in this particular construction has been and is an important issue for the theory of grammatical Case. Section 6 reviews what kind of typology is possible to allow for Double-Nominative languages and Unique-Nominative languages. Section 7 summarizes the article.

subsection.heading: 2.1 The Double Nominative Double Subject Construction
subsection.p: In a language like English, on the basis of which the theory of generative grammar has mainly developed, the position of the subject and the assignment/checking of the Nominative Case have been taken to be unique for a clause:

(2)
a. John's uncle is a doctor.
b. *John uncle is a doctor. 1
This is not the case in Japanese. In Japanese, having two or more Nominative Subjects is possible:

(3)
a. Jon -ga isha -da.
John NOM doctor is
‘John is a doctor.’
b. Jon -ga oji -ga isha -da.
John NOM uncle NOM doctor is
‘It is John whose uncle is a doctor.’
c. Jon -ga oji -ga me -ga chikai.
John NOM uncle NOM eye NOM near
‘It is John whose uncle is nearsighted.’

In the classical treatment of the Nominative Case, as in Chomsky (1981, 1986a), the Nominative Case of the subject is assigned by the subject's being governed by a category INFL(+ Tense/Agr), in the following structure:

(4)
[IP NP [I′ INFL(+Tense,AGR) VP]]
(NP assigned Nominative)

Due to the convention of the X-bar theory at that time, the number of the specifier (SPEC) of the phrase has been considered to be one, so the number of NPs with the Nominative Case is also considered to be one. Thus, the position of the subject has been regarded as unique. The existence of the Double Nominative Construction is peculiar in this context. Even though the position of the subject and the position of the Nominative Case (regarded as identical at that time) are taken to be unique, why do Japanese and some other languages allow for having two or more Nominative phrases per clause? We have five choices (or maybe more) to answer the question:

(5)
a. The uniqueness requirement on the Nominative Case assignment is under parametrization, and, for languages like Japanese, multiple assignment of the Nominative Case feature is allowed.
b. The Nominative Case in languages like Japanese is not assigned. The existence of the Case particle (-ga in the case of Japanese) guarantees the Case feature. There is a requirement of uniqueness on Case assignment, but not on Case particles. This type of analysis is often connected with the fact that the Nominative in Japanese often expresses the discoursal focus.
c. The Nominative Case in Japanese and other double subject languages is not assigned by the functional category INFL(+Tense/Agr). It is assigned to a particular lexical position, such as Spec(VP). Because the lexical projection does not need to be and is not unique in any respect, we can have multiple subjects.
d. The Nominative Case in languages like Japanese is always licensed by some semantic relation, which is usually called ‘aboutness’. For example, the Nominative Case in (3b) is licensed by the fact that the uncle's being a doctor is ‘about’ John.
e. The Nominative Case Assignment and the requirement that the clause have a subject (the Extended Projection Principle (EPP)) can be satisfied by separate structural relations. For example, the EPP can be satisfied by the existence of Spec(IP), while the Nominative Case assignment can be satisfied by some other structural relations, allowing for seemingly double subjects.
These possible analyses do not necessarily contradict each other and researchers often take two or more positions at the same time. We will return to the previous analyses in later sections.

subsection.heading: 2.2 Topic and subject
subsection.p: The subject is not always with the Nominative Case in Japanese. In the following example, the Nominative Subject is preceded by the topic of the sentence:

(6)
Hanako -wa Taroo -ga tazune -ta.
Hanako TOPIC Taro NOM visit PAST
Hanako, Taro visited.
In many such cases, we can easily find the non-topicalized version, in which the topic is with a grammatical relation other than the subject (object in the case of (6)):

(7)
Taroo -ga Hanako -o tazune -ta.
Taro NOM Hanako ACC visit PAST
Taro visited Hanako.
However, there are cases where the topic cannot find the ‘source’:

(8)
a. [NP Shinbun -o yomi -tai hito] -wa Asahi -ga koko -ni ari -masu.
newspaper OBJ read want person TOPIC The Asahi NOM here LOC exist PRES
‘As for those who want to read newspapers, we have The Asahi here.’
b. *[NP Shinbun -o yomi -tai hito] -gaNOM
Asahi -ga koko -ni ari -masu.
c. *[NP Shinbun -o yomi -tai hito] -oACC
Asahi -ga koko -ni ari -masu.
etc.

These ‘pure’ topics are associated with the sentence by some sort of ‘aboutness’ relation, as I indicate in the gloss. Once we take a view that the Double Nominative Construction is licensed by the semantic/pragmatic ‘aboutness’ relation, we need to distinguish the Double Nominative Construction and topics as in (8), and find the source(s) of the differences between the two constructions.

subsection.heading: 2.3 The Nominative Object Construction
subsection.p: The Nominative case is not always assigned to the semantic subject. In the following examples, the Nominative Case is assigned to those phrases which are regarded as objects in English and other languages:

(9)
a. Taroo -ga eigo -ga hanas -e -ru.
Taro NOM English NOM speak can PRES
‘Taro can speak English.’
b. Taroo -ga Hanako -ga suki -da.
Taro NOM Hanako NOM fond of PRES
‘Taro likes Hanako.’
c. Watashi -ga mizu -ga hoshi -i.
I NOM water NOM want -PRES
‘I want water.’

The fact that the Nominative Case can be given to the object in some constructions is often regarded as evidence that the Nominative Case assignment in Japanese is not structural. On the other hand, some researchers say that this is evidence that the Case assignment in Japanese is not unique, and that multiple Case assignment/checking is possible.

In sum, the existence of the Double Nominative Construction in Japanese is still under various interpretations. This is partly because the notions ‘Double Subjects’ and ‘Double Nominatives’ are not necessarily identical, as we have seen in the preceding two subsections.

subsection.heading: 3 Focus/exhaustive listing and Subjectivization
subsection.p: Kuno (1973c) points out that the main distinctive feature of the two seemingly subject-marking particles −wa and −ga in Japanese is in the discoursal informational status of noun phrases marked with them:

row.entry: -Ga marks the subject of the sentence in either neutral description or exhaustive listing.
Neutral description (only occurs with predicates representing an action, existence, or temporary state)
Exhaustive listing (obligatory with predicates representing a stable state)
‘John and only John is a student.’

subsection.p: Even though Kuno uses completely different terms for them, neutral description and exhaustive listing are both representations of the discoursal focus. The exhaustive listing -ga focalizes only the noun phrase marked with it, while the neutral description -ga focalizes a larger domain. What is important here is that -ga is not a mere Nominative marking particle, but also can mark a discoursal focus. 2 With a predicate representing a stable state, the -ga-marked phrase is interpreted as exhaustive listing.
This generalization about the distribution of exhaustive-listing -ga collapses in the following examples:

(11)
a. Kono kurasu -wa dansei -ga yoku deki -ru.
this class TOP male NOM well able PRES
‘Speaking of this class, the boys do well.’
b. Kono kurasu -wa Jon -ga yoku deki -ru.
John
‘Speaking of this class, John does well.’ (Kuno 1973c: 64 (10))

In (11a), even though the predicate deki ‘able’ expresses a permanent state, the noun phrase marked with -ga, namely dansei-ga, is ambiguous between neutral description and exhaustive listing. Ga with a stative predicate is not always interpreted as exhaustive listing. On the other hand, the noun phrase Jon-ga in (11b) is always interpreted as exhaustive listing.

To account for this fact, Kuno cites two other facts. First, (11a) has a corresponding non-topical sentence, where the sentence-initial phrase kono kurasu-wa is not topicalized but marked with the Nominative Case. On the other hand, (11b) does not have such a corresponding sentence:

(12)
a. Kono kurasu -ga dansei -ga yoku deki -ru.
this class NOM male NOM well able PRES
‘It is this class in which the boys do well.’ (Kuno 1973c: 67 (16b))
b. *Kono kurasu -ga Jon -ga yoku deki -ru.
John
‘It is this class in which John does well.’ (Kuno 1973c: 68 (18b))
In (12a), it is Kono kurasu-ga but not dansei-ga which is interpreted as exhaustive listing. Thus, we can obtain the following generalization:
(13) The leftmost noun phrase marked with -ga in a sentence with a predicate which expresses permanent state must be interpreted as exhaustive listing.

In (12a), kono kurasu-ga must be an exhaustive-listing noun phrase because it is the leftmost phrase marked with -ga. As for (11a), there are two possibilities. First, (11a) can be (12a) with the first Nominative phrase kono kurasu-ga topicalized. In this case, the interpretation of -ga-marked phrases goes as in (12a), and dansei-ga is a neutral description phrase. The second possibility is that (11a) be (14) with the genitive phrase topicalized:

(14)
Kono kurasu -no dansei -ga yoku deki -ru.
this class GEN male NOM well able PRES
‘The boys in this class do well.’ (Kuno 1973c: 68 (21))

In that case, it is the noun phrase kono kurasu-no dansei-ga which must be interpreted as exhaustive listing, because it is the only Nominative phrase in the sentence. The ambiguity of (11a) is thus accounted for.

Then the question is: why is such ambiguity impossible for (11b)? To account for this, Kuno cites another fact. It is possible to have a genitive source for (11b), as we show (14) corresponding to (11a), but the semantics of the genitive relations is different, according to Kuno:

(15)
Kono kurasu -no Jon -ga yoku deki -ru.
this class GEN John NOM well able PRES
‘John, who is in this class, does well.’ (Kuno 1973c: 73 (33b))

In (14), the genitive relation is restrictive, while in (15), it is non-restrictive. Kuno suggests that this difference may be the reason why we cannot have (12b) (see Kuno 1973c: 73, fn. 8). On the basis of these observations, Kuno formalizes the following Subjectivization Rule:

(16)
Subjectivization:
Change the sentence-initial NP-no (with some semantic relation; see the above observation (K.T.)) to NP-ga, and make it the new subject of the sentence.
(Kuno 1973c: 71 (28a))
Subjectivization, for example, shifts the structure (17a) to (17b):

(17)
a. [S [NP [NP kono kurasu -no]
dansei -ga] yoku deki -ru.] (= (14))
b. [S [NP kono kurasu -ga] [S [NP dansei -ga] yoku deki -ru.]] (= (12a))

(15) cannot undergo Subjectivization because the genitive relation in it, being non-restrictive, is not one of those semantic relation that can trigger Subjectivization. Thus, Kuno (1973c) has established the basis for the later works on the Double Nominative Construction.

subsection.heading: 4 After Subjectivization: analyses on Double (Nominative) Subjects
subsection.p: Kuno's Subjectivization approach to the Double Nominative Construction is certainly one example of a fine pure syntactic analysis of previously unknown grammatical facts. However, it gives rise to the following two problems:

(18)
a. Is the genitive–head relation the only source of Subjectivization or the Double Nominative/Subject Construction? In other words, is the Double Nominative/Subject Construction always ‘derived’ by movement/adjunction?
b. How can we assign the Nominative Case to the ‘derived’ subjects?

(18b) will be dealt with in sections 5 and 6, where the mechanism of Nominative assignment is directly dealt with. This section will introduce approaches to (18a). It will be pointed out that derivation from the genitive position is not the only source of the Double Nominative Construction, but the Double Nominative Construction can also be licensed by what we call ‘aboutness’. There are even scholars who say that ‘aboutness’ is the only distinctive feature of the Double Nominative Construction, and that there is no such rule as Subjectivization.

subsection.heading: 4.1 Kuroda on Major Subject
subsection.p: Taking up Kuno's ingenious analysis of the Double Nominative Construction, Kuroda (1986) points out that all Double Nominative sentences cannot be derived by ‘Subjectivization’:

(19)
Tokyoo wan -no sakana -ga koozyoo haisui -ni -yoru
Tokyo bay GEN fish NOM factory drained water DAT by
kaisui -no osen -de moo sudeni sisha -ga san
sea water GEN pollution by already already dead person NOM three
-mei de -tei -ru.
persons come out PROG PRES
‘It is fish of Tokyo Bay that due to the pollution of sea water by water drained from factories the death of three persons has already happened.’
(Kuroda 1986: (129))
(19) does not have the genitive source which Subjectivized sentences do:

(20)
Tokyoo wan -no sakana -no koozyoo haisui -ni -yoru
Tokyo bay GEN fish GEN factory drained water DAT by
kaisui -no osen -de moo sudeni sisha -ga san
sea water GEN pollution by already already dead person NOM three
-mei de -tei -ru.
persons come out PROG PRES
Kuroda calls such an extra subject Major Subject.
Kuroda, on the basis of this and other examples, claims that the extra Nominatives (and topics) are licensed in the following structure:
That is, provided that NP can hold a proper predication relation with the rest of the sentence, the extra subject can be semantically licensed.
In addition, Kuroda in his earlier work (1978) notes that there are two types in the predication relations held in the Double Nominative sentences derived by Subjectivization. Consider (22) and (23):

(22)
[S Zoo -ga [S hana -ga naga -i]]
elephant NOM
trunk NOM long -PRES
‘It is elephants that have long trunks.’ (Kuroda 1978: (64))

(23)
[S kono hana -ga iro -ga kirei -da]
this flower NOM color NOM beautiful PRES
‘It is this flower whose color is beautiful.’ (Kuroda 1978: (65))

(22) is derived by Subjectivization from a sentence zoo-no hana-ga naga-i and the derived subject is Chomsky-adjoined to an S node. However, in (23), the extra subject is sister-adjoined. Kuroda distinguished between the two because, in (23), the predicate kirei-da is involved in two predication relations, namely that the color is beautiful and the flower is beautiful, but, in (22), the extra subject holds a predication relation with the rest of the sentence as a whole (the sentence does not imply that elephants are long). This type of distinction still must be reflected in the structural analysis of Double Nominative sentences.
Moreover, Kuroda (1986) points out that there are apparent topics which cannot alternate with -ga:

(24)
Shinbun -o yomi -tai hito -wa koko -ni ari -masu.
newspaper ACC read want people TOP here LOC exist PRES
‘Those who want to read newspapers, (you find) them here.’
(Kuroda 1986: (145))
(25) *Shinbun -o yomi -tai hito -ga koko -ni ari -masu.

Kuroda correctly points out shinbun-o yomi-tai hito-wa is not even a topic of the sentence in (24), because the sentence is not about those who want to read newspapers but about newspapers. Kuroda claims that this is the reason why (25) is impossible. The ‘topic’ phrase in (24) cannot hold any predication relation with the rest of the sentence. 3 So far, we need to distinguish at least four kinds of topics and subjects in Japanese structurally or semantically.

subsection.heading: 4.2 Pure Topic
subsection.p: Tateishi (1994) points out that, in addition to examples like (24) which Kuroda uses, there is a group of real topics which cannot alternate with -ga:

(26)
a. Tarooi
-wa Jiroo -ga Hanako -ni karei
-no musuko -o shookai -shi -ta.
Taro TOP Jiro NOM Hanako DAT he GEN son ACC introduce do PAST
‘As for Taro, Jiro introduced his son to Hanako.’
b. Hannin -wa Saburoo -ga ayashi -i.
perpetrator TOP Saburo NOM suspicious
‘As for the perpetrator, I suspect Saburo might be.’

As the glosses show, the two -wa phrases are topics of the sentence, and, in this sense, they can hold proper predication relations with the rest of the sentences. According to Kuroda's statement in the previous section, this may be enough for licensing the Nominative Case on such topics. However, topics in (26) cannot alternate with -ga:

(27)
a. *Tarooi -ga Jiroo -ga Hanako -ni karei -no musuko -o shookai -shi -ta.
b. *Hannin -ga Saburoo -ga ayashi -i.

These examples show that the domain of predication relations and the domain of Nominative assignment are not identical. We need to distinguish at least five types of Double/Multiple Subject Constructions:

(28)
a. Subjectivization I: The derived subject holds a predication relation with the main predicate. (= (23))
b. Subjectivization II: The derived subject holds a predication relation with the rest of the sentence as a whole. (= (22))
c. Major Subject: No genitive origin. The extra subject holds a predication relation with the rest of the sentence as a whole. (= (19))
d. Pure Topic: No Nominative alternation. The extra topic holds a predication relation with the rest of the sentence as a whole. (= (26))
e. Non-Topical ‘Topic’: No Nominative alternation. No predication relation. (= (24))
If these distinctions must be stated in terms of structural distinctions, we need to have four clausal domains at least:

(29)
a. The domain in which the subject can hold a predication relation with the main predicate. (vP?)
b. The domain in which the Nominative Case is assigned. (IP or TP)
c. The domain in which the predication relation is possible. (Somewhere between IP and CP)
d. The whole clausal domain. (CP)

subsection.heading: 4.3 Mihara on ‘aboutness’
subsection.p: Mihara (1994), in his book on Japanese syntax, claims that all Double Nominative sentences are licensed in terms of the notion ‘aboutness’. He claims that, provided that the sentence is ‘about’ the subject/topic, the Nominative assignment is licensed. Take the example in (19) from Kuroda (1986), which is repeated in what follows:

(30)
Tokyoo wan -no sakana -ga koozyoo haisui -ni -yoru
Tokyo bay GEN fish NOM factory drained water DAT by
kaisui -no osen -de moo sudeni sisha -ga san
sea water GEN pollution by already already dead person NOM three
-mei de -tei -ru.
persons PROG PRES come out
‘It is fish of Tokyo Bay that due to the pollution of sea water by water drained from factories the death of three persons has already happened.’
(Kuroda 1986: (129))
The meaning of (30) can be paraphrased as in (31):
(31) Fish of Tokyo Bay are such that the death of three persons by eating them has already come out due to the pollution of sea water by water drained from factories.
According to Mihara it is this “such that” relation which allows for the generation of an extra subject.

However, Mihara's claim cannot stand as is when we look at the Pure Topic. The Pure Topic sentence is also connected with the rest of the sentence by what Mihara calls an ‘aboutness’ relation, but the Pure Topic cannot be Nominative-marked. ‘Aboutness’ cannot explain everything about Double Nominatives, though it may be that Double Subjects/Topics are licensed by ‘aboutness’ or predication relations. 4

subsection.heading: 4.4 Tateishi's non-movement analysis
subsection.p: Tateishi (1988) proposes an analysis of Subjectivization from a different point of view. He notices the fact that Subjectivization has a genitive origin. For Tateishi, for example, example (1), repeated here as (32), has the structure of (33):

(32)
Nihon -ga kokumin -no heikin jumyoo -ga mijika -i.
Japan NOM citizen GEN average lifespan NOM short PRES
‘It is Japan whose citizen's average lifespan is short.’
(33) [IP [NP Nihon -ga [NP kokumin -no heikin jumyoo -ga]] [VP mijika] -i]

For Tateishi, the extra Nominatives stays in situ in a Genitive position. The Nominative Case is assigned to the Genitive position by a kind of Case feature percolation. Thus, there is no movement involved in Subjectivization, according to Tateishi (1988).

Heycock (1993) criticizes Tateishi's analysis on the basis that an adverb can be inserted between the two Nominative phrases, casting doubt on the constituency of the two Nominative phrases as a whole:

(34)
Nihon -ga zannen-nagara kokumin -no heikin jumyoo -ga mijika -i.
Japan NOM unfortunately citizen GEN average lifespan NOM short PRES
‘It is Japan whose citizen's average lifespan is unfortunately short.’

However, we must say that it is still conceivable that movement seemingly involved in Subjectivization is a kind of Scrambling and that, if so, the Nominative assignment in situ is still a possibility. Independently of this, Tateishi (1994) points out that Scrambling of subjects in the Double Nominative Construction is possible. For example, (33) can undergo Scrambling and have the following word order:
(35) Kokumin -no heikin jumyoo -ga nihon -ga mijika -i.

Tateishi (1994) has refuted Tateishi's (1988) analysis on the basis of this fact on Scrambling, because it appears that, if (32) is the correct structure, (35) involves movement of a non-maximal constituent. However, once Scrambling of the subject is possible, we can derive (35) by moving the Nominative phrases twice:
(36) [NP tj Kokumin -no heikin jumyoo -ga]i NP nihon -ga]j ti mijika -i.
Thus, Tateishi's (1988) analysis still remains as a formal possibility.

subsection.heading: 5 Nominative assignment
subsection.p: This section and the next introduce studies trying to answer (18b), repeated here as (37):
(37) How can we assign the Nominative Case to the ‘derived’ subjects?

This section introduces those which propose mechanisms of Nominative assignment, and section 6 introduces studies which try to explain the existence of the Double Nominative Construction by parametrization of a part of language faculty.

subsection.heading: 5.1 Saito's analysis of Nominatives
subsection.p: Saito (1982, 1985) proposes that the Nominative Case -ga in Japanese is a kind of inherent Case. In Saito (1982), he appears to identify the trigger of this inherent Case to be a focus. As -ga is an inherent Case triggered to be generated by some kind of thematic or semantic relations, -ga phrases can be generated more than once, Saito states.

The most serious trouble with Saito's approach is that it is actually very hard to identify the triggering semantic relation for the Case particle -ga. As we have mentioned in section 3, it is true that -ga in the root context expresses a kind of focus, neutral description, or exhaustive listing. However, as Kuroda (1986) correctly points out, -ga is not always focal in the non-root context:

(38)
[Moshi zoo -ga hana -ga mijika -kereba] dono yoo -ni shi -te banana -o tabe -ru -daroo.
if elephant NOM trunk NOM short if how way DAT do and banana ACC eat PRES Q
‘If elephants had short trunks, how would they eat bananas?’
(Kuroda 1986: (106))

There is no indication of focus in the conditional clause in (38), as the focus of questioning here is on how elephants eat bananas. Thus, it is not clear what -ga expresses, except that -ga may be Nominative. There is no strong evidence which shows that -ga is inherent.

subsection.heading: 5.2 Multiple Nominative assignment
subsection.p: Takezawa (1987; Takezawa and Whitman 1998) proposes that the existence of the Double Nominative Construction in Japanese is due to the lexical characteristic of the category INFL in Japanese. In English, the number of Nominative-marked phrases in a tensed clause is one, because INFL requires a strictly one-to-one Case-assignment/checking relation with a noun phrase. On the other hand, according to Takezawa, Japanese allows for a single INFL assigning/checking the Nominative Case with two or more noun phrases, allowing for Double Nominatives.

Such an analysis of Case assignment/checking works, and it may be advantageous given the fact that there is a distinction between a Double Subject Double Nominative construction and a Double Subject Topic construction (see section 4). Such a distinction may well be described in terms of the domain of Nominative assignment/checking. In fact, Ura (2000) recently proposes a view that Case feature checking may be parametrized between one-to-one and multiple for his analysis of Double Subject Constructions. The only flaw in this kind of account is that it is speculative and ‘parametrization’ of the lexical item INFL/Tense comes from nothing else. This is what the studies introduced in section 6 are exploring.

subsection.heading: 6 Functional categories and Double Nominatives
subsection.p: As we have seen in the previous section, there is a possibility that some kind of parametrization is involved in the existence/absence of the Double Nominative Construction. However, is it just a simple direct description of the fact? For example, is the parametrization in question of the form [+/− unique Nominative assignment/checking], as Takezawa (1987) and perhaps Ura (2000) argues for? Studies introduced in this section try to answer this question. They all claim that the peculiarity of the Double Nominative Construction comes from something deeper.

subsection.heading: 6.1 Kuroda and Fukui's parametrization approach
subsection.p: Fukui (1995) and Kuroda (1988) both try to derive a set of differences between languages like English and those like Japanese from a simple parametric difference which covers the very basic of clausal construction. For example:

(39)
Japanese
English
Lack of surface wh-movement Obligatory wh-movement
Scrambling No Scrambling
Stacks of Determiner-like elements Unique Determiner per Noun Phrase
No grammatical plural form which triggers agreement Number agreement required
Multiple Nominatives allowed Unique Nominative per clause
Though they differ in the details of their formulation of the parameter in question, it can be stated as follows:
(40) English forces agreement, while Japanese does not force agreement or lacks agreement at all.

As agreement in the current syntactic theory is basically a feature-checking relation between the head and the Spec in the projection of functional categories (Chomsky 1995c), the lack of agreement means the lack or inertness of functional projections. Thus, languages like Japanese must generate virtually everything in lexical projections, according to Fukui and Kuroda. The lexical projections are not under the control of feature checking and there are basically no bounds to the number of levels of projections in terms of X-bar theory or whatever replaces it (e.g., there are no bounds to the number of adjectives preceding and modifying a noun). Thus, in a language like Japanese where the subject is in the lexical projection on the surface, the multiple subjects are possible, so far as there can be a proper semantic relation between the subject and the rest of the sentence:
(41) [I′ [VP NP-ga [VP NP-ga [VP NP-ga . . . ]]]]
Thus, the multiple Nominatives are possible, according to Fukui and Kuroda.

Then what is the Nominative Case? On this issue, Kuroda and Fukui differ. Kuroda claims that -ga is marked and licensed whenever a noun phrase is clause-initial. Kuroda views Case in Japanese as something assigned based on linear positions, not on structural relations. Fukui, on the other hand, claims that -ga and other Case particles are of a special syntactic category K(ase), and K is generated to Case-mark an NP in languages like Japanese where structural Case assignment/checking is not possible.

The major weak point of Fukui's and Kuroda's approach is that they cannot distinguish the types of Topics/Subjects introduced in section 4. However, their approach to Japanese grammar is worth exploring in that they try to derive numbers of differences in two types of languages from a single, simple parametric difference, which possibly simplifies the form of Universal Grammar drastically.

subsection.heading: 6.2 Case particles as functional heads
subsection.p: Whitman in Takezawa and Whitman (1998) shows a unique view on Japanese Case marking. He agrees with Fukui that the case particles in Japanese constitute independent syntactic categories and are not simply a marking on NP. He differs from Fukui in that Whitman considers case particles as fully projecting functional categories. For example, for Whitman, a simple transitive sentence in Japanese has the following structure:

(42)
[IP Taroo [I′ [I -ga] [TrP Hanako [Tr′ [Tr -o] [VP shikatta]]]]]
Taro
NOM
Hanako
ACC
scolded
‘Taro scolded Hanako.’

For Whitman, the Nominative Case particle -ga is an instance of a functional head INFL and the Accusative Case particle -o is an instance of another functional head Tr(ansitive) (or v or AgrO or whatever we call it), and the clausal structure in Japanese has full projections, just like English. Case marking/checking is done by the Spec–Head relations just as in English. Japanese is different from English in that INFL lacks Tense/Agr features, basically following Fukui's and Kuroda's claims. Because Japanese INFL -ga lacks features, it can be multiplied in a single clause, according to Whitman:

(43)
[IP Zoo [I′ [I -ga] [IP hana [I′ [I -ga] [AdjP nagai]]]]]
elephants
NOM
trunk
NOM
long
‘It is elephants whose trunk is long.’
The two INFL -gas are responsible for the two occasions of Nominative marking/checking.

The problem which immediately arises from Whitman's treatment of Japanese grammar is that we cannot conceive of a way to derive a sentence to which Scrambling of a noun phrase has applied, where a noun and a case particle appear to move together as if they constitute a constituent, as in (42):
(44) Hanako -o Taroo -ga shikatta.

A noun and a case particle following it always move together, and Whitman's grammar does not have a way to guarantee this. However, his way of analyzing Japanese clauses is worth exploring, because it may show another direction the theory of Universal Grammar may head in once parametrization of the characteristic of functional heads, as proposed by Fukui and Kuroda, can be accepted as something real.

subsection.heading: 7 Conclusion
subsection.p: This article has introduced theories and analyses of Japanese Double Subject/Nominative Constructions. It has been shown that this peculiar construction may be a guiding light for various branches of syntax, such as focus, the basic clausal structure, topic/subject distinction, and the role of functional heads in grammar. So far, there has not been any theory of this construction which covers all of the characteristics/distinctions that are introduced and reviewed in this article. Future studies on the Double Nominative Construction must be both theoretically intriguing and descriptively accurate, as almost all issues relating to this peculiar construction have been presented.
